Award.AbstractNarration:
BROADER SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROJECT:

This REU Site program will provide rigorous training in research methods for undergraduate students in the fields of mechanical engineering, manufacturing engineering, and materials science and engineering. Particular attention will be paid to underrepresented students in order to ensure program diversity and students from institutions with limited STEM opportunities in order to provide research opportunities to students that otherwise cannot access these opportunities. The program will provide undergraduate students with the opportunity to engage with industrial experts and will encourage the students to pursue graduate education. Investment in this program will help the United States maintain a competitive advantage in the critical manufacturing technology of Additive Manufacturing (AM).

The effort will foster interest in a key competitive technology area and provide valuable knowledge related to the following components: 1) a ten week summer program on AM research that combines analytical studies and computer aided design and analysis with a hands-on laboratory experience, 2) challenging individual research projects utilizing the skills of mechanical engineering, manufacturing engineering, materials science and engineering, and information technology, to address critical issues in AM, 3) structured mentoring system for the students that includes a network of students and faculty, 4) opportunities where industry and faculty experts discuss topics such as state-of-the-art research, emerging technologies, etc., and 5) an environment where students learn effective communication in a variety of media.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION:

This three-year program at Missouri University of Science and Technology (Missouri S&T) is focused in the area of Additive Manufacturing (AM). Each year ten undergraduate students will join the Missouri S&T team of faculty and graduate students to engage in exciting, interdisciplinary AM research. To meet the interdisciplinary nature of AM, the proposed program will be a joint effort of the Departments of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Manufacturing Engineering, Material Science and Engineering, and Information Science and Technology, as well as the Center for Aerospace Manufacturing Technologies on the Missouri S&T campus.

The goals of this REU Site program are to: 1) educate undergraduate students to the awesome possibilities AM allows and stimulate them to learn more, 2) provide students with individual challenging research projects in AM that include analytical, computer aided design and analysis, and hands-on components in world class facilities with state-of-the-art equipment, 3) attract talented undergraduate students, particularly underrepresented students (at least 35% female and 20% minority) and students from institutions with limited STEM research opportunities (at least 50%), to conduct research in AM and motivate them to pursue graduate studies, and 4) provide activities that expose the students to other exciting areas of research and cutting?edge technologies, improve their communication skills, etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU Site program at the Missouri University of Science and Technology (Missouri S&T) focused on providing research training for undergraduate students in the exciting and challenging area of Additive Manufacturing (AM). A total of 31 undergraduate students joined the Missouri S&T team of faculty (13) and graduate students (37) and engaged in exciting, interdisciplinary AM research. In addition, this program has partially supported 29 other undergraduate students conducting AM research. These affiliated students were mainly funded by the Missouri S&T Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering and the Department of Energy National Security Campus in Kansas City operated by Honeywell. In this program undergraduate students learned how to select a research topic, conduct a literature review, formulate and execute a research plan, and disseminate research results via a variety of media. Each research project was mentored by at least one graduate student and one faculty member. The graduate students had the opportunity to learn how to provide a meaningful mentoring experience to junior personnel. They learned how to guide undergraduate students in selecting and executing their research projects, conducting themselves professionally, and presenting their work through a variety of media. The faculty also honed their mentoring skills by providing oversight for both undergraduate and graduate research and by mentoring graduate students on how to be mentors.

 

The undergraduate students engaged in a wide variety of AM research. One project was concerned with the additive manufacturing of glass for gradient indexed optics, optical circuits, etc.  Experimental studies were conducted to understand relationships between process parameters and part quality. The students started with filament-fed processes and later developed the equipment and knowledge to fabricate parts using fiber. Freeform structures were fabricated and glass to metal seals studies were conducted. Another area of research the undergraduate students engaged in was laser metal deposition, which is the logical alterative to metal powderbed additive processes for part repair and adding engineering features to large parts. Advanced process planning techniques to minimize part height variation were conducted, as well as studies to create better methods for remanufacturing, which will positively impact the environment. Select laser melting, a popular metal power bed process, was investigated. The relationship between process parameters and part mictrostructure was analyzed, as well as the range of variations that occur in the process. Thermal camera data was gathered and processed to analyze and control AM power bed builds, which will be critical to the verification of these processes. Students created modal analysis techniques to determine part defects in a non-destructive manner. Students also researched the aerosol ink jet printing process, which is used to create three dimensional electronics, flexible electronics, and bioresorable printed electronics. Their work consisted of powder preparation, understanding the effect the substrate material plays on the part morphology in the aerosol ink jet printing process, and identifying conductive nanoparticle inks that are suitable for these processes. Another research project that was conducted was ceramic on demand extrusion process. The students investigated preparing zirconium diboride (ZrB2) paste, hydrogels that were bioactive and printable, and low temperature co-fired ceramic extrudate. Another student investigated optimally removing binder used in these processes.

 

This project promoted diversity and provides research opportunities for undergraduate students from institutions with limited Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) research opportunities. Of the 31 undergraduate students fully funded by the REU program, 13 were female, five were black, four were Hispanic, and 14 were from institutions with limited STEM research opportunities. Of the 29 affiliated undergraduate students, six were female, four were black, and seven were from institutions with limited STEM research opportunities. The undergraduate students developed their technical communication skills by presenting their research bi-weekly at group meetings and by writing bi-weekly research reports. In addition, this program developed a technical communications program that consisted of three two-hour, interactive workshops directed by a technical communications expert at Missouri S&T, and a one hour one-on-one mentoring session on technical report writing, technical presentation preparation and delivery, and on preparing and delivering a technical poster. The undergraduate students presented their poster to the Missouri S&T community and at the International Solid Freeform Fabrication Symposium, the premier research conference on AM. At the conference the undergraduate students learned about the latest research in AM and had the opportunity to interact and network with researchers from all over the world.
